evidence.detectionMethod: Exome sequencing failed to pick up a mutation initially, Targeted sequencing based on proteomics studies and modified variant calling settings identified the variant, confirmed by Sanger.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Proband was hospitalized for gastric bleeding during febrile period of clinical gastroenteritis at 2m of age. Gastroscopy showed profuse bleeding in the presence of striking leukocytosis (Leukocyte count: 25.2 - 55.8 × 10e6/mL). Mean platelet volume: 8.8 fL, from 9 samples (nv = 7.4-11.7 fL).

Second hospitalization due to S. aureus perichondritis that resulted in scarring of right pinnacle. At 5m, proband presented with fever and purpuric lesions on legs, arms and scrotum and poor wound healing. Skin biopsy showed leukocytoclastic vasculitis with multiple microthrombi. Vasculitis was associated with increased eosinophil count (3350 cells/μL at 25m with infection). Treatment with corticosteroids set eosinophil count at normal, which remained within the normal range thereafter.

At 4y, proband had bloody diarrhea due to Salmonella typhimurium infection, associated with pan-colitis with neutrophil and eosinophil infiltration in colon biopsies. Pneumonias responded to antibiotics, but led to mild brinchiectasis; eczema was serious. Proband developed anaphylaxis after ingesting nuts.
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Proteomics analysis of the proband's platelets and neutrophils indicated a complete lack of ARPC1B.

F-actin polymerization defect was apparent with neutrophil chemotaxis defect on confocal analysis. Enhanced azurophil granule release was seen upon cell acivation, but normal phagocytosis and killing of S. aureus and E. coli was seen. Platelet spreading was different from that of control platelets, GPIIb/IIIa activation was intact.

dc:source.dc:creator: Kuijpers TW
dc:source.dc:title: Combined immunodeficiency with severe inflammation and allergy caused by ARPC1B deficiency.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kuijpers_Proband

evidence.dc:description: The proband was homozygous for a delins variant, a deletion of 5 bp and an insertion of 7 bp. The variant resulted in a frameshift that resulted in premature termination of translation. The parents of the proband were heterozygous for the variant.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing was performed and mutations confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Proband had hemorrhagic enteritis, history of cold abscess in lung requiring hospitalization

dc:source.dc:abstract: ARPC1B is a key factor for the assembly and maintenance of the ARP2/3 complex that is involved in actin branching from an existing filament. Germline biallelic mutations in ARPC1B have been recently described in 6 patients with clinical features of combined immunodeficiency (CID), whose neutrophils and platelets but not T lymphocytes were studied. We hypothesized that ARPC1B deficiency may also lead to cytoskeleton and functional defects in T cells. We have identified biallelic mutations in ARPC1B in 6 unrelated patients with early onset disease characterized by severe infections, autoimmune manifestations, and thrombocytopenia. Immunological features included T-cell lymphopenia, low numbers of naïve T cells, and hyper-immunoglobulin E. Alteration in ARPC1B protein structure led to absent/low expression by flow cytometry and confocal microscopy. This molecular defect was associated with the inability of patient-derived T cells to extend an actin-rich lamellipodia upon T-cell receptor (TCR) stimulation and to assemble an immunological synapse. ARPC1B-deficient T cells additionally displayed impaired TCR-mediated proliferation and SDF1-α-directed migration. Gene transfer of ARPC1B in patients' T cells using a lentiviral vector restored both ARPC1B expression and T-cell proliferation in vitro. In 2 of the patients, in vivo somatic reversion restored ARPC1B expression in a fraction of lymphocytes and was associated with a skewed TCR repertoire. In 1 revertant patient, memory CD8+ T cells expressing normal levels of ARPC1B displayed improved T-cell migration. Inherited ARPC1B deficiency therefore alters T-cell cytoskeletal dynamics and functions, contributing to the clinical features of CID.
dc:source.dc:creator: Brigida I
dc:source.dc:title: T-cell defects in patients with ARPC1B germline mutations account for combined immunodeficiency.

evidence.rdfs:label: Brigida_Proband P5

evidence.dc:description:
The proband was homozygous for a 1-bp deletion that causes a frameshift and premature termination of translation. The proband's mother was heterozygous for the variant.

The evidence is awarded reduced points for consanguinity.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing was performed and mutations confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Proband showed lifelong recurrent bacterial infection at cutaneous and mucosal sites. Along with dysregulation of oxidative burst response in neutrophils, T cell lymphopenia and disappearance of naïve T lymphocytes was observed. Died at 24y due to pneumonia.
evidence.rdfs:label: Brigida_Proband P3

evidence.dc:description:
The proband was homozygous for a 1-bp duplication that causes a frameshift and premature termination of translation. The resulting transcript is not expected to undergo NMD as this termination occurs toward the 3' end. However, the functional significance of the abnormal protein is unknown.

The evidence is awarded reduced points for consanguinity and since NMD is not expected.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing was performed and mutations confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Proband presented with gluteal abscess treated by antibiotics and surgery at 23d of age. At 4m, hospitalized for pulmonary (left lung) abscess, requiring mechanical ventilation. Platelet count = 91.000/mmc. At 11m, he had sepsis due to S. pettenkoferi infection. He also had a history of chronic anemia, hemorhhagic enteritis, early-onset severe chronic eczema, inflammatory colitis with GI bleeding.
evidence.rdfs:label: Brigida_Proband P4

evidence.dc:description:
The proband was homozygous for a nonsense variant, Trp86Ter, and the parents were each heterozygous for the variant. The variant is expected result in a very short transcript that is expected to undergo NMD.

The evidence is awarded reduced points for consanguinity.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing was performed and mutations confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Proband presented at 2m with fever, polymorphic vasculitic rash, hepatosplenomegaly and hematochezia. Platelet count = 80.000-130.000/mmc, MPV = 6.9-9 fL. Proband had macrophage activating syndrome, but bone marrow aspirate negative. high-dose steroids proved effective. Gancyclovir given at 4m for CMV reactivation. Proband had recurrent pustular vasculitic skin lesions and Pseudomonas-caused otitis. Persistent lymphopenia required anti-PCP prophylaxis.

Progressive lymphoadenomegaly appeared at 2y of age. Growth hormone therapy was ineffective. At 4y, fever with elevation of inflammatory indices, cervical lymphadenopathy and a painful and harsh mass at the right abdominal wall with macrophage muscular infiltrate at biopsy was seen that responded to steroids and rapamycin. Peripheral blood stem cell transplant from father performed at 5y.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Mutations in RMRP, PSTPIP1 and RAG genes were excluded
evidence.rdfs:label: Brigida_Proband P2

evidence.dc:description:
The proband was homozygous for the missense variant, Val208Phe predicted to be damaging by in-silico tools as it could destabilize the protein structure and lead to incorrect folding.

Extensive immunological investigations were performed in the proband that showed T-cells failed to spread and emitted aberrant filopodia, failed to assemble an immunological synapse, failed to migrate on in-vitro assay.

The evidence is awarded minimal points due to the lack of evidence on the functional significance of the variant expressed in-vitro.

evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted sequencing on 630 genes implicated in primary immune deficiency was performed and mutations confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Disease onset at 1m of age. Recurring episodes of hemorrhagic enterocolitis, S. typhi in stools, lower limbs and abdomen leucocytoclastic vasculitis. Reduced platelet count (38.000-97.000/mmc) and reduced mean platelet volume (<7.7 fL). Proband had staphylococcal upper right lobe pneumonia with residual pneumatocele, surgically removed at 5y. Pneumonia recurred due to P. aeruginosa infection.

At 9y of age, painful nodules in the upper limbs associated with arthromyalgia, required antibiotic therapy. Purpura treated with steroids. Mycophenolate Mofetil and Rapamycin had adverse reactions.

Patient had HSCT from mother
evidence.rdfs:label: Brigida_Proband P1

evidence.dc:description:
The proband was homozygous for the splice donor variant, while the parents were heterozygous for the variant. The variant is reported once in gnomAD in the non-Finnish European population. (0.000009258)

Structural modeling for the c.64+1G>C variant showed insertion of 7 additional hydrophobic amino acids at the loop between the first two β-strands, which might interfere with protein folding and aggregation with other subunits.

Extensive immunological investigations were performed in the proband that showed T-cells failed to spread and emitted aberrant filopodia, failed to assemble an immunological synapse, failed to migrate on in-vitro assay.

The evidence is awarded default points.

evidence.detectionMethod: WES of the proband and parents was performed.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Evaluated at infancy for colitis, eczematous rash, papulovesicular lesions on the scalp and severe thrombocytopenia. Proband had CMV pneumonitis later and was on IVIG treatment and prophylactic antibiotics. Immunologic abnormalities and megakaryocytic hyperplasia, mild eosinophilia were observed on analysis.

At 5y, proband developed severe adenovirus infection leading to multiorgan failure and death, while awaiting bone marrow transplantation.
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
T cell receptor and B cell receptor repertoires were determined by sequencing variable regions of TRB, TRG, IGH and calculating V(D)J gene usage.

21 other candidate genes were also analyzed by sequencing.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Regulation of the actin cytoskeleton is crucial for normal development and function of the immune system, as evidenced by the severe immune abnormalities exhibited by patients bearing inactivating mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP), a key regulator of actin dynamics. WASP exerts its effects on actin dynamics through a multisubunit complex termed Arp2/3. Despite the critical role played by Arp2/3 as an effector of WASP-mediated control over actin polymerization, mutations in protein components of the Arp2/3 complex had not previously been identified as a cause of immunodeficiency. Here, we describe two brothers with hematopoietic and immunologic symptoms reminiscent of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). However, these patients lacked mutations in any of the genes previously associated with WAS. Whole-exome sequencing revealed a homozygous 2 bp deletion, n.c.G623DEL-TC (p.V208VfsX20), in Arp2/3 complex component ARPC1B that causes a frame shift resulting in premature termination. Modeling of the disease in zebrafish revealed that ARPC1B plays a critical role in supporting T cell and thrombocyte development. Moreover, the defects in development caused by ARPC1B loss could be rescued by the intact human ARPC1B ortholog, but not by the p.V208VfsX20 variant identified in the patients. Moreover, we found that the expression of ARPC1B is restricted to hematopoietic cells, potentially explaining why a mutation in ARPC1B has now been observed as a cause of WAS, whereas mutations in other, more widely expressed, components of the Arp2/3 complex have not been observed.
dc:source.dc:creator: Somech R
dc:source.dc:title: Disruption of Thrombocyte and T Lymphocyte Development by a Mutation in ARPC1B.

evidence.rdfs:label: Somech_Patient 1

evidence.dc:description:
The proband and his brother were homzygous for the 2-bp deletion that caused a frameshift and premature termination of translation. The parents were both heterozygous for the variant.

No expression of ARPC1B protein was detected upon immune staining of patient's bone marrow with anti-ARPC1B, indicating that it may be absent or truncated.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing was performed and mutations confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Proband showed syndromic features including keratotic hair lesions, peculiar face, big thumb and hallux, early release of the upper gumsdysplastic teeth.

At 15d, she presented with S. aureus positive lung and joint abscesses, bloody diarrhea, bacterial meningitis. Perianal and vulvar necrotizing ulcerations, evolving in lichenoid lesions were reported. Skin biopsy showed HPV-positive epidermodysplasia verruciformis.

Platelet count = 37.000 to maximum 112.000/mmc. Proband also had aregenerative anemia, systemic inflammation. GI endoscopy showed inflammatory infiltrates, total villous atrophy, apoptosis in jejunum and colon, without any improvement on steroid and azathioprine. Infections included S.aureus skin infection, CMV pulmonary infection, Actinomyces cutaneous infections.

Brain CT scan at 2.5y showed left carotid sinus aneurysm. MRI at 3.5y showed dysplastic lesion of both internal carotid arteries requiring embolization at 9y.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Karyotype, FISH 22q11 and CGH array were normal. Sequencing of coding regions for RMRP, STK4, STAT3, STAT5B and IGFALS were normal. NGS of 270 genes implicated in known primary immunodeficiencies revealed two missense variants in DOCK8, which were predicted to be benign.
evidence.rdfs:label: Brigida_Proband P6

evidence.dc:description:
The proband was homozygous for the splice donor variant, c.64+1G>A. The proband's parents were heterozygous for the variant. It is reported in gnomAD at frequency of 0.00008401 in African population and a total frequency of 0.00001117, with no homozygotes.

Structural modeling for the c.64+1G>A variant showed insertion of 7 additional hydrophobic amino acids at the loop between the first two β-strands, which might interfere with protein folding and aggregation with other subunits.

Extensive immunological investigations were performed in the proband that showed T-cells failed to spread and emitted aberrant filopodia, failed to assemble an immunological synapse, failed to migrate on in-vitro assay.

The evidence is awarded default points.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing of patients and their parents
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Proband had neck abscess and meningitis at 1m of age, with septic shock and superior sagittal sinus thrombosis with left posterior parietal-infarction due to Staphylococcus aureus infection, bloody diarrhea due to rotavirus infection at 5m, marked papular and nodular rash (vasculitis) at 9m. Repeated bone marrow analysis showed increased eosinophils. Low albumina and rectal bleeding at 3y, Repeat colonic biopsy showed severe eosinophilic infiltration in the colon and rectum. Periodic flaring of rash started at age 4 and showed leukocytoclastic vasculitis with depositions of IgG, IgM and C3 on biopsy. Proband had mild joint limitation in the elbows and wrists with slow progression to bony erosions and was found to have positive ANA at 1/640 with an unclear pattern and intermittently positive ANCA.

Disease flares treated by short-term systemic corticosteroids with good response. S.aureus infections continued at age 6, with recurrent blepharitis of both eyes. At 9y, proband maintained on antimicrobial prophylaxis, monthly IVIG infusions and daily MMF. Microthrombocytopenia was persistent. Platelet count: 18 × 10e9/ l)

dc:source.dc:abstract: Human actin-related protein 2/3 complex (Arp2/3), required for actin filament branching, has two ARPC1 component isoforms, with ARPC1B prominently expressed in blood cells. Here we show in a child with microthrombocytopenia, eosinophilia and inflammatory disease, a homozygous frameshift mutation in ARPC1B (p.Val91Trpfs*30). Platelet lysates reveal no ARPC1B protein and greatly reduced Arp2/3 complex. Missense ARPC1B mutations are identified in an unrelated patient with similar symptoms and ARPC1B deficiency. ARPC1B-deficient platelets are microthrombocytes similar to those seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome that show aberrant spreading consistent with loss of Arp2/3 function. Knockout of ARPC1B in megakaryocytic cells results in decreased proplatelet formation, and as observed in platelets from patients, increased ARPC1A expression. Thus loss of ARPC1B produces a unique set of platelet abnormalities, and is associated with haematopoietic/immune symptoms affecting cell lineages where this isoform predominates. In agreement with recent experimental studies, our findings suggest that ARPC1 isoforms are not functionally interchangeable.
dc:source.dc:creator: Kahr WH
dc:source.dc:title: Loss of the Arp2/3 complex component ARPC1B causes platelet abnormalities and predisposes to inflammatory disease.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kahr_Patient 1

evidence.dc:description:
The proband was homozygous for the a 2-bp duplication that causes a frameshift and premature termination of translation in exon 4. The authors predict that this would result in a truncated protein lacking five of six WD40 repeat domains that form a β-propeller required for interaction of ARPC1B with other actin filaments.

Immunoflorescence microscopy of proband's skin and intestinal biopsy showed no expression of ARPC1B. Immunoblot on platelet lysates showed absence of ARPC1B and increased levels of ARPC1A (expected to be <6% of ARPC1B in normal platelets). TEM and IF analysis showed microthrombocytopenia, clinical lumi-aggregometry confirmed reduced dense granule ATP release. Platelet aggregation was normal with various agonists.

Proband-derived platelets formed spiky structures with tubulin-rich tips when spread on fibrinogen-coated surface. Area of spreading was reduced compared to normal platelets.

The evidence is awarded reduced points due to  consanguinity.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing of patients and their parents
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Extensive cradle cap at 8 weeks of age, eczematous rash on hands, followed by target lesions, purpura and swelling; skin biopsy revealed leukocytoclastic vasculitis with deposition of IgM and C3. Proband was ANA and ANCA positive. Brain MRI and angiography showed no evidence of vasculitis. Treated with corticosteroid and IVIG. Platelet counts were low to normal.
evidence.rdfs:label: Kahr_Patient 2

evidence.dc:description:
The proband and his older brother, who had subclinical manifestations, were homozygous for a missense variant, Ala105Val.

Immunoflorescence microscopy of proband's skin and intestinal biopsy showed reduced expression of ARPC1B. Immunoblot on platelet lysates showed greatly reduced levels of ARPC1B and increased levels of ARPC1A (expected to be <6% of ARPC1B in normal platelets). Clinical lumi-aggregometry confirmed reduced dense granule ATP release. Platelet aggregation was normal with various agonists.

Proband-derived platelets formed spiky structures with tubulin-rich tips when spread on fibrinogen-coated surface. Area of spreading was reduced compared to normal platelets.

Note, Proband was also homzygous for the Ala238Thr missense variant, predicted to be neutral. It is reported in gnomAD at a frequency of 0.0002943 in South Asians and 0.0002095 in non-Finnish Europeans, with no homozygotes.

The evidence is awarded reduced points due to the absence of functional evidence supporting damaging effect of the missense variant.

Proteomics analysis showed absence of ARPC1A, isoform of ARPC1B, in normal neutrophils, T cells and platelets, but present in other non-hematopoietic tissues. Expression of ARPC1A and ARPC1B was variable in non-hematopoietic cells. Analysis of primary fibroblasts for migration defects as seen with ARPC1B-deficient neutrophils showed normal migration. The authors conclude that the two isoforms have redundancy in non-hematopoietic cell lines, but since ARPC1B is the only isoform expressed in hematopoietic cells, mutations in ARPC1b lead to a hematological and immunological disease
evidence.rdfs:label: Kuijpers_ExpressionA

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is not scored any points as expression studies have not been performed sufficiently to prove the selective expression of ARPC1B in hematopoietic cells.

Immunoblotting confirmed absence of APC1B protein and showed increased ARPC1A expression in KO cells relative to wild-type cells. ARPC1B knockout cells formed proplatelets much less frequently than wild-type cells when induced with thrombopoietin to form proplatelet-like extensions in culture. While wild-type cells formed proplatelets containing tubulin and branched actin filaments, ARPC1B-null cells did not.
evidence.rdfs:label: Kahr_FA

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is awarded no points as it is not clear how the loss of ARPC1B leads to the associated phenotype.
Proliferation of ARPC1B+ cells was similar to that of controls.
evidence.rdfs:label: Brigida_Rescue

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is awarded minimal points.

Development of thrombocytes that was impaired by morpholino knock-down was rescued by human wild-type ARPC1B. The mutant, c.624_625del, did not rescue the phenotype. Using a heat-inducible expression system and whole-mount in-situ hybridization, the authors show rescue of T lymphocyte development by the human wild-type but not mutant ARPC1B.
evidence.rdfs:label: Somech_Zebrafish Rescue

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is awarded minimal points.

The loss of arpc1b protein resulted in impaired devlopment of T cells and thombocytes. Thrombocytopenia and immune anomalies are phenotypes associated with Platelet abnormalities with eosinophilia and immune-mediated inflammatory disease.
evidence.rdfs:label: Somech_Zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is awarded minimal points as it does not completely recapitulate patient phenotype in humans, and there is not enough data on the progression of disease.

In Arpc1b-/- mice, the authors noted increased IgE levels. In 75% of the KO mice, mild inflammation of the aorta and/or mesenteric and pancreatic arteries was noted. When mice were challenged with attenuated S. typhimurium M525, KO mice showed signs of moderate salmonellosis, with 8/18 mice having to be sacrificed subsequently. Wild-type mice survived the challenge.
evidence.rdfs:label: Kuijpers_Mouse

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is awarded minimal points.

dc:description:
ARPC1B was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Platelet abnormalities with eosinophilia and immune-mediated inflammatory disease in 2017 by Kahr et al. (PMID: 28368018). At least 10 loss of function (indel, deletions, duplications, nonsense) and missense variants have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data.  
  
Summary of Case Level Data: 12 POINTS 
Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 10 probands in 4 publications (PMIDs 30254128, 28368018, 27965109, 29127144). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 2 additional family members. More evidence is available in the literature (PMID: 30771411), but the maximum score for genetic evidence and/or experimental evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. 
  
The mechanism for disease is expected to be homozygous loss of function (PMID: 28368018).
  
Summary of Experimental Data: 2 POINTS  
This gene-disease association is supported by animal models and in vitro functional assays (PMIDs 30254128, 28368018, 27965109, 29127144). However, 
  
In summary, the ARPC1B-autosomal recessive Platelet abnormalities with eosinophilia and immune-mediated inflammatory disease gene-disease relationship is definitive. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hemostasis/Thrombosis GCEP on July 22, 2020. (SOP Version 7)
